This provision connotes two things: - (1) The appropriation is to be for the purposes pf the Commonwealth. In my opinion, this confines and limits the objects of appropriation to those which can be lawfully administered by the Commonwealth. (2) Given valid objects of appropriation the manner of appropriation is restricted to that authorized by the Constitution, that is to say, in conformity with sections 53-57 of the Constitution dealing with the rights and privileges of the two Houses inter se with regard to money Bills. And see also sections 83, 87, 89, and 93.

It follows, therefore, that the Main Roads Development Act 1923-1925, requires for its support that the subject with which it deals must fall within the subjects allotted to the legislative power of the Commonwealth. If I am right as to this there are, as it seems to me, only two powers to which the Act could possibly, by any sort of argument, be referred.. The first of these is the trade and commerce power, s. 51 (pi., 1) and s. 51 (pi. vi.), military defence. As to the trade and commerce power, I think this affords no support to the statute, for it fails to take notice of the necessity for roads of an interstate character, and deals generally with intra-state roads (sections 8 and 9 of the Main Roads Development Act 1923; sections 6 and 7 of the Main Roads Development Act 1925), nor does it limit its application to roads useful to interstate trade. See also regulations 3, 4, 5, and 6 (Statutory Rules, 1923, No. 104)'.
Similarly with regard to military defence the Act and the regulations ignore - indeed, negative - t.lip factor of utility for defence purposes. The regulations clearly disclose the plan of the

Commonwealth Government, at least in part, to open up and develop new country by means and with the aid of the statute (see regulation 4, Statutory Rules 1923, No. 104). I do not see, therefore, how it is possible to defend the Act either by reference to the trade and commerce power or to the military defence power. But I should say that if the Act is to be defended, the Commonwealth Government will rely upon section 96 of the Constitution. This provides that during a period of ten years after the establishment of the Commonwealth, and thereafter until Parliament otherwise provides, the Parliament may grant financial assistance to any State on such terms and conditions as the Parliament thinks fit.

In my opinion, this provision does not apply to and cannot be used to support the Act, for the following reasons: - (1) The scheme contemplated by the Act is not intended as " financial assistance " to the States as such. It embodies the Commonwealth's own policy, and is thrust upon the States against their will. Section 96 contemplates a State in need of and willing to accept " the financial assistance." If and so far as it does yield financial assistance to the States, this is merely incidental to the main purpose of the Act. (2) The section cannot be used, alio intuitu, so as to permit the Commonwealth to encroach upon the powers- left to the State. And if the course pursued can be justified as regards roadmaking, .it is not easy to see where the line can be drawn beyond which the Commonwealth may not transgress. It may, e.g., invade the field of education, housing, agricultural settlement, or any other purely State topic under cover of "financial assistance." (3) It may be said that the financial assistance may be refused; that its acceptance only requires the voluntary assent of the States. But this is more plausible than sound, since the money to be raised to administer the scheme is drawn by the Commonwealth from all the people of the various States, so that any State which refused the " financial assistance " would still be bound to yield in taxation sums of money to be spent in other States which accepted the proposals. The scheme, therefore, is a mere simulacrum of voluntary agreement so far as the individual States are concerned. (4) Moreover, the scheme shows that the expenditure of the money is irrespective of the financial needs of the various States. Its allocation follows a stereotyped formula, and is distributable among all the States whether necessitous or otherwise. In short, it is a device to execute works outside the ambit of Federal power by the agency of the States, who have no voice in the application of the " financial assistance " except as an echo of the Federal command. (5) Lastly, the terms and conditions upon which the financial assistance is provided are those which " Parliament thinks fit " to exact. No doubt Parliament may delegate its powers to a Minister in an appropriate case and where no contrary intention appears. (Baxter versus Ah Way, 8 C.L.R., p. 26). But I am disposed to think that on the true construction of this section the terms and conditions are those which Parliament itself declares, and not such as may be left to the discretion of the Minister. 5134 Federal Aid . [SENATE.] Roads Bill.

I am accordingly of opinion that the Main Roads Development Act 1923-1025 is ultra vires. In my opinion, a suit may be instituted by the State of South Australia for appropriate declarations, challenging the Act and the appropriations made under it, and for an injunction forbidding the appropriations and their application to the disclosed object.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable senator think that, in the event of litigation, Mr. Smith, K.C., would be prepared to accept a brief from the Commonwealth Government to prove that the legislation is constitutional?

- I do not know; but I am of the opinion that members of the legal profession are at all times prepared to plead in the cause of justice. I understand that they take an oath to that effect when they are admitted to the Bar. If the South Australian Government desires to retain Mr. Smith-
- I was referring to the Commonwealth Government. '

talker.name: PRESIDENT, The
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon J Newlands

talk.start.para: - I ask the honorable senator to confine his remarks to the bill.
- The Minister in charge of the bill could, no doubt, answer the honorable senator's question by communicating with Mr. Smith.
- The honorable senator's, remarks are not relevant to the bill.
- The distinguished King's Counsel, Mr. Smith-
- Order !

- Should I be in order, Mr. President in saying that, in view of the opinion expressed by eminent counsel, including the Attorney-General, Mr. F. V. Smith, K.C., and leading legal authorities in Victoria, I consider this bill to be ultra vires ? Three of the States, for various reasons, have rejected the agreement. The Victorian Government has done so on the ground that it considers that the money should be spent in the State in which it is collected. In South Australia, where, under a Labour Government, the people are so prosperous that the number of motor cars in proportion to the population is greater than in any other State, the reason is much the same. The Government of South Australia feels that it should not be called upon to build roads in Western Australia and Queensland, which are reputed to -be richer States. South Australia, being well governed
- Does the honorable senator imply that Queensland is badly governed ?

- No; it is well governed. I can understand the attitude of an honorable member in another place, who said that he was prepared to accept the grant for his State with both hands. That honorable member came from Western Australia, which State, under these proposals, will be treated better than South Australia. I am here in the interests of South Australia, and I object to my State being called upon to contribute to the cost of roads in other States. Some of the States will not accept these proposals. Bad feeling will exist between at least three of the States and the Commonwealth.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Senator Thompson) adjourned.

debate.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: .- I move -

quote.para: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the bill being passed through all its stages without delay.

speech.para: Honorable senators must not take the motion as meaning that it is intended to have an all-night sitting. I have moved it to enable the measure to be proceeded with without any delay.

talk.start.para: . - I should like to have the assurance of the Leader of the Senate that it is not intended to go right through with the bill to-night.
- Not if it means sitting beyond 11 o'clock.
- The debate on another measure has been adjourned.
- It will be resumed.
- Is it intended to put the Federal Aid Roads Bill right through to-night?
- If possible.
- Accepting the assurance of the right honorable gentleman, I shall not object to the motion.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill (on motion by Senator Crawford') read a first time.
Federal Aid[10 August, 1926.] Roads Bill. 5135

quote.para: That the Senate, at its rising, adjourn until 11 a.m. to-morrow.

talk.start.para: . - Why should the Senate meet at 11 o'clock to-morrow?
- To enable us to finish the business.
- The notice-paper has upon it only the Federal Aid Roads Bill, and that which has just been received from the House of Representatives.
- We shall also have to consider the Cotton Bounty Bill and the Estimates.

- The passage of this motion will not prevent an all-night sitting. Honorable senators ought to have been advised earlier that they were to be called together at 11 a.m. to-morrow. If another place were waiting for us to complete certain measures I could understand the necessity for an earlier meeting than usual.
- The other House met at 11 o'clock this morning, and will meet at the same hour tomorrow morning.
- If we met at the usual hour to-morrow afternoon we could keep pace with the other House, and dispose of all the business that is sent to us. I shall not agree to the motion.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: . - I am not particularly concerned with the legal aspect of this question, to which so much attention was paid by Senator Barwell, who, I think, was effectively answered by Senator McLachlan. As a layman, I consider that section 96 of the Constitution meets all objections on the grounds of unconstitutionality. I have had sufficient commercial experience to know that lawyers frequently differ and dependence cannot be placed on any opinion that they give. I rose particularly to say that as far back as March last, I received from motor users in Queensland a number of requests to which I sympathetically replied. I was urged by them to believe that the whole of the cost of this scheme would be borne by the motor users of Australia. Since then I have been subjected to a continuous stream of correspondence, which in the last few days has culminated in protests from all sorts of bodies. I have received telegrams and letters from personal friends, and from institutions with which I have been connected for many years. They have a very healthly fear that this will impose a tremendous tax upon those who use motors. If my friends had had the advantage of having the position explained to them as clearly as it has been explained to us, I feel sure that they would not urge me to protest against this measure. Motor users will have to bear only a portion of the tax. It is claimed that the owners of other vehicles should be called upon to provide a percentage of the amount that the Government requires. Unfortunately this Government cannot enter that arena, because it would undoubtedly be an invasion of State rights. It proposes to use the only avenue that is open to it, namely, that offered by the imposition of a duty. The acceptance of the agreement by the Queensland Government induces me to give the measure the support that it ought to have. That State especially is crying out for good roads. I have no doubt that at a later period the States which are now standing out will be pleased to come into the scheme. I do not anticipate the litigation of which Senator McHugh appears to be so afraid. I am not surprised at the attitude which is being adopted by the Government of New South Wales, because this Government is anathema to Mr. Lang and his followers, and they would not accept any proposal that it advanced. I am pleased to find Victorian senators supporting the bill, and I am sure that eventually this State will accept the agreement. There is no occasion for the strong protests that have been made by the oil companies. They will derive an advantage from a larger consumption of petrol when an improvement in the quality of the roads brings about a greater volume of motor traffic. They will be justified in refraining from passing on the extra 2d. per gallon. Senator Payne, by interjection, said that these duties" are always passed on. On occasions they are not. It would be wise for the oil companies to bear the extra cost. Even if the consumers of petrol are asked to pay a higher price, I" am. assured by those who are qualified to express an opinion that good roads will enable them to effect a saving on tires, and in other directions which will more than cover the extra cost of petrol. The proposal is in the interests of motor users, the oil companies, and the nation in particular. I therefore have much pleasure in supporting the bill.

. - There can be no difference of opinion concerning the urgent necessity for a progressive roads policy for the Commonwealth. Australia cannot be developed without good roads." If we fail in that respect we shall be unable to keep pace with other countries which have given greater attention to the question of roads construction. We have also to recognize the fact that motor transport, which is essential for the proper development of any country, has not only come to stay, but is rapidly increasing.

speech.para: The agreement contains provisions which, in my opinion, are grossly unfair. I do not know whether I shall be in order, Mr. President, in referring to the method by which the money is to be raised to carry out this project.

talker.name: PRESIDENT, The
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon J Newlands

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator is entitled to refer only incidentally to that aspect of the question.

- When the Main Roads Development Bill was before the Senate last year, £1,750,000, all of which came out of the genera) revenue, had been provided by the Federal Parliament for the inauguration of a roads scheme. That was contributed by the whole of the people, and I cannot understand why more extended reference has not been made to the injustice of asking a section of the people, as is now proposed, to contribute the whole of the money required to carry out a national roads scheme.
- A contribution of £500,000 per annum is' to be made from the general revenue.

- Yes; but £1,500,000 will have to be found by a section of the people to provide works of general utility. After giving the activities of this and preceding Governments the closest attention I cannot discover one instance in which the Government has expended in the interests of the whole people, public funds which have been contributed by only one section. In perusing the bill I find that on certain roads essential to the community not one penny will be spent, although those who use them will have to contribute the money to be raised by the imposition of an additional duty on petrol. It would be impossible to mention any city in Australia which has not arterial roads leading to it that are of the utmost importance to those living outside. There are a number of motorists, commercial and otherwise, whose business never takes them beyond the confines of the cities, but who will have to make a heavy contribution towards this fund, and who will not benefit in the slightest degree. I have received two letters in connexion with this matter. One is from the Mayor of Hobart, and reads -

quote.para: I have received a letter from the honorary secretary of the Melbourne Metropolitan Conference (Mr. W. R. Butcher, Town Clerk, Collingwood) on the Federal Roads Grant, drawing attention to the fact that under the terms of the Federal grant all towns and cities whose population exceeds 5,000 are excluded entirely from the operations and benefits of the grant, and asking my council to cooperate in endeavouring to have this remedied. I must say that it appears to me extremely unfair that in cases such as Hobart, where at least three of our streets are practically main roads, we should not derive some advantage from the proposed tax, and I would be very glad if you will be good enough to give the matter your special attention and endeavour to obtain for us a reasonable amount of benefit from the grant. . . .

speech.para: I have also received the following communication from the town clerk of the city of Launceston - _

It has been brought under the notice of the council that, under the terms of the Federal roads grant all towns and cities whose population exceeds 5,000 are excluded entirely from the provisions and benefits of the grant, despite the fact that the motorists of the above-mentioned towns and cities will contribute 70 per cent, of the revenue devoted to the grant. This will, doubtless, appeal to you as being a most inequitable arrangement, particularly as the bulk of the revenue to be devoted to the construction of country main roads is to be derived from additional duties on petrol, tires, and chassis from the motorists, of whom the abovementioned percentage operate constantly on metropolitan roads. As taxation implies service, it will be readily admitted that it would be sound in principle to give such service in the shape of good roads to those motorists who supply the revenue for roads, yet the claims of the city motorists have been entirely ignored. . . .

It appears to me that the representatives of these councils have made out a good case for special consideration if this project is to be carried out. When a member of the Tasmanian Parliament, I took a great interest in Tasmania's development, and since I have been a member of the Federal Parliament, in the development of the whole Commonwealth. No one has been more energetic and enthusiastic in advocating good roads than I have been, but, although I wish this scheme to become operative, I am entirely opposed to the method by which the money is to be raised.

talk.start.para: - In what way does the honorable senator suggest the money should be raised ?
- It should come out of the general revenue, and if sufficient is not available from .that source, a loan should be raised for the purpose.
- - Does the honorable senator think that the Commonwealth Government should interest itself in road construction ?

- Yes, because it is more imperative in the interests of the Empire than it has ever been to proceed with a progressive developmental policy, and no State is at present sufficiently strong financially to incur the expenditure inseparable from carrying out a comprehensive roads policy. Notwithstanding all that has been said concerning the unconstitutionality of this measure, ' federation was established in the interests of the whole of Australia, and the Constitution provides that the Commonwealth can render financial assistance to the States in order to ensure their development. My principal objection to the bill is that it is not fair to ask one section of the community to meet three-fourths of the expenditure involved. In order to raise sufficient money to cover the .cost of road maintenance, every State has found it necessary to impose a special tax on users of motor vehicles and almost every other vehicle. This direct tax, which is fairly heavy, varies in amount, but, in addition, indirect taxation is imposed in the form of municipal rates, to which will have to be added the further tax which the Commonwealth authorities propose to levy.

talker.name: PRESIDENT, The
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon J Newlands

talk.start.para: - I direct the honorable senator's attention to the fact that there is nothing in the bill concerning the method by which the money to finance the scheme is to be raised.

- I admit that; but I do not see how I can intelligently discuss the measure, which provides for the expenditure of a huge sum of money, without at the same time referring to the system under which it is proposed to raise that money. In view of the limitations imposed upon me, I shall conclude by repeating that I approve of the Federal authorities assisting the State Governments, but am strongly opposed to the method by which the money is to be collected.

. - I intend to support the second reading of this bill, as I believe it will assist the development of the Commonwealth. It is well known that the country districts cannot be properly developed under the present' system of road construction, as the local governing bodies have not sum'cient funds at their disposal to undertake extensive road-construction schemes. All their revenue is used in maintaining roads already constructed, and unless additional money is raised by way of loans, further construction is practically impossible. It was announced during the election campaign that if the Government were returned, it .would embark on a comprehensive roads scheme.
- But no mention was made of the imposition of an additional tax on petrol.

- That phase of the question cannot be discussed on this bill, but may be considered when the measure under which the additional rate is to be imposed is before the Senate. A good deal has been said concerning the constitutionality of the Government's proposal to make grants to the States for road construction purposes ; but, in my opinion, section 96 of the Constitution permits that to be done. Even legal authorities, however, differ on the point. I was chairman of a Court of Petty Sessions for about six years, and gave a number of decisions, only one of which was challenged. Honorable senators, I think, have been somewhat confused by the difference in the opinions of legal gentlemen as to the constitutionality of this bill. All I can say is that, if it is unconstitutional for the Commonwealth to spend public revenues on road construction, possibly the States will be asked to repay the ?1,750,000 which they have already received from the Commonwealth Government for this purpose. I am afraid there will be very little chance of getting it. Roads are essential to the proper development of the Commonwealth. We have adopted the Government's migration proposals, and before long we shall be expecting a steady stream of migrants from the Mother Country. The other day I had a conversation with the head of the Salvation Army in Victoria on the subject. He told me-
- (Senator the Hon. J. Newlands) - I must ask the honorable gentleman not to discuss, in connexion with this bill, the migration proposals of the Government.

- The State Governments will be required to submit a roads programme extending over five years. I am wondering if it will be possible to set aside some portion of the money for the construction of roads to open up new settlements. Unfortunately, the' cost of construction is increasing from year to year. The first contract I made with gas companies for tar was on the basis of from 5d. to 6d. a gallon. To-day the price is about ls.- 2d. a gallon. It is impossible for the States, unaided, to carry out -a great- roads construction programme. The agreement provides that towns with a population exceeding 5,000 shall not participate in money allocated under the agreement. This will operate unfairly in the cases of a large number of municipalities which have main roads running through their territories. For example, the main roads from Melbourne to Echuca, and from Melbourne to Mildura, pass through a number of towns with a population exceeding 5,000, so the provision limiting any expenditure under this agreement to main roads outside the boundaries of such towns will penalize the municipalities mentioned.
- Why should not Melbourne also participate in the grant?

- I understand that municipalities in the metropolitan areas have made representations for an extra ?5,000,000 to meet their needs. No doubt that proposal will receive consideration in due course. Exception has also been taken to the roads policy being administered by the Commonwealth Government. On this point I direct attention to the clause which states that the Ministers for Public Works in the various States, together with the Minister of State for the Commonwealth, shall . comprise a board which shall have the direction of policy. From what I know of State Ministers, I am satisfied that their presence on the board will materially influence its policy. It has also been objected that the allocation to some of the States will be less than the amount contributed by them under this scheme. Probably Victoria will suffer to the extent of ?1,000,000, but we should regard these proposals from a Federal stand-point. We should not forget that the Commonwealth has' contributed ?2,500,000 towards the cost of the river Murray . scheme, which will benefit primarily the States of New South Wales, Victoria, and South Australia. Nor should we forget that in four year's the Commonwealth has assisted the iron and steel industry in New South Wales to the extent of ?667,331, and South Australia to the amount of ?245,000 in connexion with the wine bounty. We should discuss all proposals such as this in a purely Federal spirit. I agree with the principle of the bill. The method by which the money is to be raised will be dealt with in another measure. I support the bill because I believe it will play an important part in the development of Australia.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 4 agreed to.
Schedule.

talk.start.para: . - I direct attention to clause 7 of the agreement in the schedule, which provides that, where a road passes through a town whose population does not exceed 5,000, it shall be constructed as if the town did not exist. Does this apply only to new townships? Many municipalities whose population exceeds 5,000 are responsible for the maintenance of main arterial roads over which a heavy volume of tourist traffic passes. Are they to be shut out? I have in mind such centres as Claremont, Iremantle, and Subiaco, suburbs of Perth, as well as similar municipalities in the metropolitan areas of the other States.

. - The clause applies to every centre whether metropolitan or rural, and the governing factor is the number of its inhabitants. If there are 5,000, or more, no money can be contributed under this bill towards the cost of road construction in that centre, but if the population is under 5,000 a Commonwealth grant can be so applied. A desire has been expressed for certain amendments of the schedule, but I point out that it constitutes the agreement arrived at in conference with the States. If any amendment were made, the States as a whole would have to be consulted again; and since that would cause great delay, I suggest that the agreement should be not amended except for the gravest possible reason.
. - It now appears that the large centres of population will not benefit under the agreement.
- If they do not exceed 5,000 in population, they are included.
- The Minister knows that between Perth and Fremantle are suburbs, the population of which is more than 5,000, which should be embraced in the scheme.
- Western Australia has accepted, this agreement.
- Such centres should receive consideration. I have no desire to delay the measure, but I ask that consideration of this clause be postponed.
- That would hang up the bill for months.
- In the meantime, the Minister could get into touch with the States.
- The States that have accepted it have made no complaint regarding this provision.
- I am under the impression that they do not appreciate its significance. Have the various State Governments had the agreement before them in the form in which it is now' presented to this committee?
- Yes, word for word.
- For what period have they had it?
- Ever since the conference. The schedule embodies the agreement that has been signed by three State Governments, and they are now submitting it to their Parliaments for ratification.
- The agreement was arrived at "after a most exhaustive discussion.
- Do I understand that the Premiers of Western Australia, Tasmania, and Queensland have signed the agreement in this form ?
- Yes.
- If the Parliament of Western Australia decided, on looking at clause 7 of the agreement, to reject it, what would the position be?
- The whole agreement would be rejected, so far as Western Australia was concerned.
- I take it, then, that the agreement has been signed by three of the States, and that the responsibility now rests with the State Parliaments.

.- The clause embodies an important principle, and I consider it wrong to restrict the scheme to towns not exceeding a population of 5,000. As the population, of towns increases, there is greater concentration of traffic on the main roads running through them, and the local authorities are unable to cope with the problem of maintaining those roads.
- But a town with 5,000 inhabitants, or more, has greater taxing power than one with a smaller population.

- Yes, but las the numbers increase, the rate of taxation per head becomes greater. The main road from Launceston to Hobart, as it approaches the capital city, passes through the suburban areas of Glenorchy, Derwent Park, Moonah, and Newtown, each of which has a population of over 5,000. Those towns are not financially strong enough to keep the main roads in good repair. A circular which has been sent to me states -

quote.para: It is understood that some months ago a deputation consisting of representatives of metropolitan municipalities on the mainland requested the Federal Minister for Public Works to recommend that, in addition to the £20,000,000 grant for country roads, a special grant, spread over ten years, be made to assist towns and cities with populations exceeding 5,000 in the construction of their main arterial roads, which bear an enormous amount of foreign traffic. The Minister would give no decision, but referred the deputation to the Prime Minister, who promised to look into the papers on the matter and reply, hut to date he has not stated his intention.

speech.para: It would appear that this matter has been brought under the notice- of the Government, and I cannot understand why some provision of the nature requested has not been made. If towns and cities with populations exceeding 5,000 are excluded the scheme will break down, because when the municipal boundaries are reached the roads will be so bad that motorists and others will find their journey interrupted. The agreement ought to be referred back to the States which have' signed it with a request that they should accept an amendment in accordance with the suggestions that have been made to-night.

SenatorGRANT (New South Wales) [10. 58 J. - The agreement seems to have' been hurriedly drawn as the result of a nominal conference which merely gave perfunctory attention to the subject. It is clear from correspondence I have received that there is the strongest opposition to the proposals contained in the bill. The Commonwealth Government has decided, wrongly, I think, to engage in the business of roadmaking, and that no part of the money shall be expended in towns or cities having populations exceeding 5,000. Presumably, a road from Esperance to Port Lincoln via Eucla would fulfil the requirements of the bill. A few years ago the present Attorney-General said that the Commonwealth Government had no constitutional justification for spending millions of pounds upon the construction of roads. But if the Government will persist in raising revenue for this purpose, and handing it over to the States to spend, it will do well to realize that they have a knowledge of roadmaking, and should be permitted to expend the money in a way they consider best, subject, possibly, to the formal approval of the Federal Minister for Works. It would be in the interests of the recipients of this assistance, and of roadmaking generally, if this bill were postponed until we could learn more fully the views of the people directly concerned. There is no reason why this legislation should be hurriedly forced through Parliament merely because the Government has a majority supporting; it.

talk.start.para: . I do not think that sufficient time has been given to the consideration of this allimportant measure. The more I examine it, the less favorably I am disposed towards it. The principle it contains is unsound, and the scheme itself is unfederal in spirit, and does not meet with the approval of some of the States.
-I ask the honorable senator to confine his remarks to the schedule.

- I intend to do so. Moreover, the bill does not meet with the approval of 'some of the principal municipalities in Victoria. At a very important conference of metropolitan municipalities held in Melbourne, the delegates pointed out how unfair is the proposal to exclude cities with a population of over 5,000 inhabitants. A circular which I have received from the Town Clerk of Collingwood says -

quote.para: By direction of the chairman (Councillor A. J. Dunkin, Collingwood Council) of the conference of metropolitan municipalities .on main arterial road construction, I am desired to draw the attention of all Federal members of both Houses, representing towns and cities with populations exceeding 5,000,- to. the facts that under the terms of the Federal Government's scheme for main road construction all towns and cities with populations exceeding 5,000 have been excluded from the provisions and benefits of the £20,000,000 Federal grant for main roads.

This will doubtless appeal to such members as being a most inequitable arrangement, particularly in view of the fact that the bulk of the revenue to he devoted to the construction of country main roads is to be derived through additional duties on petrol tires and chassis from the motorists of whom 70 per cent, operate constantly on metropolitan roads. As taxation implies service, it will be readily admitted that it would be sound in principle to give such service in the shape of good roads to those motorists who supply the revenue for roads. Yet the claims of the 70 per cent, mentioned have been entirely ignored.

speech.para: What answer can the Minister give? According to this circular, a deputation waited on the Prime Minister to ask for a grant of £5.000,000, but it was given no definite reply other than that its representations would receive consideration. This clause does not apply to the metropolitan district of Melbourne only, but to all cities with a population of over 5,000 persons. We must remember that motorists from all parts of the country visit the cities, and if damage is done to roads by motor traffic, these people from the country contribute to that damage. Yet, the bulk of the money, under these proposals, will he collected from the users of motor cars in the big cities of . the Commonwealth. The principle underlying these proposals is wrong. No one section of the community should be singled out to provide revenue for the making of roads and, at the same time, be precluded from participating in the grants that are made. No one would oppose a sound proposal for the construction of good roads. When the Government's roads policy was announced it was not understood that only a section of the road users would be taxed. . The Labour party believes in good roads; but it also believes that all the users of those roads . should . contribute towards their cost.

talk.start.para: - Is there anything in the schedule about money?

- Good roads cannot be constructed without money. I am anxious to see good roads throughout Australia, but I submit that if the cost of such undertakings is to be borne by road users they should be paid for by all the persons who use them, and not by only a section of them. I do not think that those States to which . this scheme is unacceptable should be called upon to provide money for the construction of roads in other States. I know that the Government supporters are pledged to support, the measures introduced by the Government

- On a point of order. I submit that the honorable senator is not dealing with the schedule, but is discussing the attitude adopted by honorable senators who support the Government. Are we to have a general discussion on the policy of the Government?

speech.para: The CHAIRMAN (Senator Plain).I have allowed the honorable senator considerable latitude. I ask him now to confine his remarks to the clause before the committee.

talk.start.para: - I appreciate the latitude that you have given me.
- The honorable senator must not take advantage of it.

- I am the last to take advantage of the Chair. At all times I endeavour to pay respect to the ooenpant of the chair, whoever he may be. There are many cities within the metropolitan area of Melbourne that hare grown considerably during recent years. A few years ago, Caulfield was not a city and its population was small. Now, it is a city with a population of considerably over 5,000 persons. Some of the roads ' in Caulfield are in bad order. More buildings have been erected in the city of Caulfield during the last few years than in any other municipality in Victoria, with the result that some of the roads have got into a state of great disrepair. It is well known also that some of the roads within the metropolitan area are so bad that children attending school are forced to walk through pools of water and slush, thereby contracting colds, which may lay the foundation for future ill health. Naturally, l am concerned about those municipalities whose population exceeds 5,000' persons. I can well understand the anxiety which the conference manifested. I do not desire to delay the passage of the bill, but I wish the Minister to make a definite - statement respecting the request of the representative gentlemen who waited on the Prime Minister recently that £5,000,000 should be spent within these municipalities.

speech.para: The CHAIRMAN (Senator Plain).The honorable senator has exhausted his time.
